review_title: John Woo gives us the silent treatment
review_detailed_main:
FILM: 6.5/10.

Embarking on my first watch of John Woo's 2023 film Silent Night, I found myself intrigued by the backstory. After the rocky reception of his 2003 film Paycheck, Woo returns to Hollywood after two decades, armed with something to prove.

Silent Night opens with a promise - a dialogue-light script that hands the reins to Woo's visual storytelling prowess. Woo, often tagged as a one-trick pony in America, dispels that notion, showcasing his versatility across genres. The film's simplicity in premise does the job, providing a canvas for his directorial finesse.

Yet, the central gimmick of a nearly mute cast becomes a double-edged sword. While initially inventive, it wears thin as the narrative progresses. Early on, the absence of audible dialogue is intriguing, but later, it risks becoming a distracting hurdle as the initial creativity wanes.

Joel Kinnaman leads the charge, delivering a fair portrayal of grief early on. However, as the film unfolds, his silent expressions of pain, anger, and frustration veer into the comical, creating unintentional moments of levity that disrupt the intended gravitas.

The film's saving grace lies in its action sequences, notably the impressive car chases. Woo's trademark slow-motion techniques are supported by the razor-sharp cinematography, providing a visceral and visually striking experience.

In Silent Night, Woo may not hit the bullseye, but he certainly hits the target. It's a return worth noting, with moments of brilliance amid occasional hiccups. For action aficionados and Woo enthusiasts, it's a watch that offers glimpses of his directorial prowess, even if the silent experiment falls a tad flat.

review_title: Good old fashioned John Woo action...
review_detailed_main:
Right, well of course it was nice to see John Woo return to direct a Hollywood movie. And naturally, I must admit that I was indeed harboring a certain level of expectations to his return to the US cinema. So how did he manage with "Silent Night"?

Essentially well enough, I would say. Sure, the script and plot in "Silent Night", as written by Robert Archer Lynn, is a bit generic and linear. There wasn't really any twists or turns to the narrative throughout the course of the 104 minutes that the movie ran for, which sort of made "Silent Night" a bit generic and rather predictable.

Sure, "Silent Night" is a watchable enough movie for what it turned out to be. But it wasn't exactly an the grand return to direct Hollywood movies that it could have been for director John Woo. Entertaining? Sure. Enjoyable? Sure? Outstanding? Not so much.

The acting in "Silent Night" were good, but I have to say that leading actor Joel Kinnaman wasn't really given all that much to work with, since his character was deprived the ability to speak. So it felt like he was left with two options throughout the course of the movie; and that was either rage or self-pity. Not really the best of writing from Robert Archer Lynn here in terms of character depth and development.

Of the entire cast ensemble in the movie, then I was only familiar with Joel Kinnaman.

Now, with "Silent Night" being a John Woo movie, there is something you can count on. And that is a good amount of action and adrenaline-packed scenes. And true enough, John Woo certainly delivered here with "Silent Night". There was an abundance of action scenes, fight scenes, car chase scenes and such, as you would expect from a John Woo movie. And it looks good and it feels very well choreographed and executed. And that most certainly made the movie all the more enjoyable to sit through.

And the ending of the movie was just a bit too sappy. It seemed like the writer was trying to add a level of sympathy for the Brian Godlock character with the audience. However, it was such a bizarre change of style to the movie, that is came off as being really campy and cheesy.

If you enjoy John Woo movies, then you definitely should sit down to watch "Silent Night". And if you are unfamiliar with previous movies directed by John Woo, then you can very much still enjoy "Silent Night" for the action movie that it turned out to be.

My rating of "Silent Night" lands on a six out of ten stars.

review_title: John Woo's Silent Night; A Tragically Shallow Experience
review_detailed_main:
Prior to watching Silent Night, I wish I was aware of how important the word 'silent' was in the title. This is not like a silent film from the early twentieth century - sound effects and music (diegetic and non-diegetic) are used; characters scream and occasionally mutter; and scenes are interspersed with the rare radio broadcast, contextualizing date and time. Apart from this, there is almost NO DIALOGUE in the entire film.

This gives all new meaning to the phrase 'actions speak louder', while inadvertently showing why verbal communication is so important. Focus instead goes to facial emotions. Brian (Joel Kinnaman) spends most of the movie switching between outrage, shock and bereavement. Brian's wife, Saya (Catalina Sandino Moreno) is mostly limited to extreme grief, and Detective Vassel (Kid Cudi) spends most of the film looking, I don't know; curious? This detracts from the main cast, by making all of them very shallow and one note - characters need to be more than just the sum of a couple emotions.

The film begins on Christmas Eve, with Brian and Saya's young son being gunned down during a drive-by between two rival gangs. In the grip of fury, Brian pursues those responsible, only to be shot in the throat by Webface (Acoyani Chacon), a wound that prohibits Brian from speaking. The film's title works as a pun, for not only does the story happen around the festive season, but on the anniversary of his son's death, Brian will take his silent revenge over one bloody night.

Though Moreno's character is severely underused, it is antagonist, Webface, who is really done dirty. Appearing for maybe a total of five minutes in the film's entirety, he becomes the focal point of Brian's rage, though it's never revealed if he is the gangster that killed Brian's son. The villains of a John Woo film are often a highlight, but here; absolutely not, and though Webface is shown to have ties to the community, in an attempt to make him morally gray, the real crime here is his complete lack of personality, depth or motivation.

Furthermore, a lot (and I mean A LOT) of the film focuses on Brian's transition from Arnold Average to Arnold Schwarzenegger after he leaves the hospital. Despite the necessity to establish Brian's change and determination, this has been done to death in other vigilante style films, and essentially feels like padding. Like Team America said, there's nothing wrong with a training montage, but scene after scene after scene after scene of it, seems overblown. I mean, at the end of the day, we're all here for the same thing, right?

In that case, John Woo's visual flare *occasionally* has a chance to shine - sadly though, there are no doves. Slow motion sequences look sublime; scene transitions are well executed and moments where characters wield two guns looks alright. Sometimes text messages and letters are used to push the plot forward, and though this works to show the growing distance between Brian and Saya, it does little else.

As an aside, I've been reading the Orphan X books, which thematically explore if a killer can maintain their humanity. This same idea is raised in Silent Night, with Brian on occasion sympathising with a criminal. However, after witnessing him kill gang members by the dozen, having him suddenly care about one villain, especially one who we witness commit a crime, is poorly handled.

To be frank, this is not a return to form for John Woo. Silent Night is unfortunately forgettable when compared with Hard Boiled or Face off.

Aside from its gimmick - that characters hardly utter a word, a schtick that seemingly works against the film - this is just another revenge thriller, akin to Death Wish, Death Sentence, Hero Wanted, or even John Wick, and with Woo's hypnotic and hyperbolic signature style largely absent, it leaves the film without much of an identity. As an experiment, Silent Night is not half bad. But as an action experience, it's just above average.

review_title: A sad return to Hollywood for John Woo
review_detailed_main:
An air of quiet excitement surrounded legendary Chinese action director John Woo's return to Hollywood with his first venture back in the system since his ill-fated Ben Affleck starring Paycheck from 2003 but that 20 year hiatus was one many wished would have continued with the lifeless and pointless exercise that is Silent Night.

A gimmicky mid-budgeted action thriller that sells itself on the fact its a film with no proper dialogue across its 100 minute runtime, one would expect with zero character development or very minor at best character investment that Woo would let his action shine but sadly for all the man that once gave us genre classics such as Hard Boiled, Bullet in the Head and cult favourites such as Face/Off can't even get that right in a film that feels past its use by date mere minutes in.

In a new age cinematic world that has been gifted modern action affairs like the double bill Raid films, the John Wick and original Jason Bourne trilogies and even The Mission Impossible brand that Woo once helmed, a stale and mostly mind-numbing genre effort like Silent Night feels like the exact type of straight to video release Netflix has made its name for over recent years with its action beats and pointless Xmas time setting unable to bring any goodness to a high-concept that fails to take off.

Front and centre to this generic revenge tale of an aggrieved father on a one man mission to murder his way through all those he perceived to have had a part in his young boys murder is the unfortunate Joel Kinnaman who keeps finding ways of signing himself up to lacklusture products and while every now and then he finds himself in a winner like 2021's Suicide Squad, Kinnaman's work outside of the TV realm has quickly established him as one of those names that has become synonymous with average to downright bad.

Joel, it might be time to find yourself a new agent buddy.

Taking forever to even get to the type of bullet filled material you thought you were signing up for, Silent Night cares little that its giving you nothing for a solid 30 - 40 minutes only to then unleash a solid hour of careless and mostly sleep-inducing action full of lots of empty cartridges and nameless goons, ensuring anyone that expected anything slightly close to the action goodness that Woo has produced in the past are going to leave this soulless exercise with nothing more than a lot of regret.

Final Say -

A unique on paper concept that gets quickly washed away by a lack of purpose, poor execution and overall blandness, Silent Night squanders its directors greatest strengths and yuletide setting on an experience that is akin to a lump of coal and empty shotgun shells in a smelly Christmas stocking.

review_title: A bittersweet return to John Woo's action
review_detailed_main: Silent Night marks John Woo's return to Hollywood, a nostalgic ride through his cinema of excess. However, the film stands out for its bittersweet melody, a work that oscillates between moments of mastery and falls into banality. The Chinese director, acclaimed for his epic Hollywood adaptations, returns with an action thriller imbued with shades of melodrama. Set on Christmas Eve, the film follows the story of Brian, an electrician played by Joel Kinnaman, whose life is shattered by the death of his son in a gang shootout. Woo, the Hong Kong master, approaches the film with a decisive attitude, focusing on the essentials and stripping away the embellishments of plot and contextualization. Brian's loss of voice becomes the key device, rendering the film almost mute and devoid of dialogue, a bold choice that helps define the silently intense tone of the work. However, despite the potential for originality, Silent Night encounters some narrative obstacles. The plot, centered on Brian's revenge against the gang responsible for his son's death, feels thin and conservative. Melodramatic clichés emerge in the family dynamics, lacking the authenticity and depth desired. The film plays with evocative visual symbols, such as the red balloon symbolizing lost innocence. Woo, while attempting to convey his authorial signature, engages in a complicated endeavor, as his vision seems discordant with modern audience expectations. The lack of dialogue, while on one hand imparting a unique atmosphere, on the other may seem like excessive artifice, compromising the emotional connection with the characters. The choice of a dark visual style and Marco Beltrami's soundtrack amplifies the resemblance to grindhouse, but at times feels out of place, especially in the Christmas violence sequences. The performances of the cast, particularly Kinnaman's, are commendable. However, the lack of psychological development of the characters relegates them to stereotypes rather than authentic individuals. Silent Night distinguishes itself in action scenes, typical of Woo's repertoire, with well-executed combat choreography and a suggestive shootout sequence on the stairs. Unfortunately, these moments of brilliance are diluted by an inconsistent and clichéd plot that leaves the audience with a sense of dissatisfaction. Silent Night represents a return to John Woo's past, but fails to fully capture the attention of the contemporary audience. A work that oscillates between the exceptional and the banal, between spectacular action and a lack of narrative depth.

From the opening heist gone wrong to the climactic showdown in a snowy cabin, Woo's signature slow-motion shots and intricate fight choreography were on full display, keeping audiences on the edge of their seats.

While the action set pieces were undoubtedly the film's highlight, the plot itself felt somewhat convoluted and underwhelming. The story revolves around a group of thieves who find themselves trapped in a remote cabin during a Christmas Eve heist, forced to fend off both the authorities and a mysterious group of heavily armed assailants. The premise had potential, but the execution often felt muddled, with too many characters and subplots vying for attention.

Visually, "Silent Night" was a feast for the eyes, with Woo's signature style lending a sleek and stylish aesthetic to the proceedings. The cinematography was top-notch, with the snowy landscapes and dimly lit interiors providing a striking contrast to the explosive action sequences. However, the film's tonal shifts were sometimes jarring, veering from intense violence to moments of dark humor that didn't always land.

While "Silent Night" delivered on its promise of high-octane action and stylish visuals, it ultimately fell short in terms of narrative cohesion and character development. Fans of John Woo's signature style and over-the-top action sequences will find plenty to enjoy, but those seeking a more well-rounded and emotionally resonant Christmas movie may be left feeling a bit underwhelmed. review_title: Good action film from John Woo.
Not Enough and Too Much John Woo
review_detailed_main:
"Silent Night" is an attempt by John Woo to be poetic rather than his usual artistic action, and it fails.

A man whose son was killed by a stray bullet during a gang car chase battle runs after them and is shot in the neck, losing his voice, and setting up the conceit: there is no dialogue in the entire movie (OK, yes, a couple very low words spoken by his wife). He falls apart then is galvanized into revenge, the usual plot.

There is some artistic Woo action, and way too much flashback pushing his agony in your face.

I grant you that it is dark and grim, with a message about society letting things happen that should be tamped down, so the only way to solve it is to "Kill Them All." But that doesn't make a good movie.

It does have great villains, though, which is one of my key criteria.

I don't know what happened here. I believe there was a good concept behind all this mess, but it got lost during production, or in the editing room, who knows.

Joel Kinnaman plays a father out for revenge after his son has been killed by a stray bullet from a gang related shooting. Real cliché story but with John Woo there is always something special - this time it's the main character's silence, since he lost his vocal cords when he was shot in the neck. Good idea, poor execution.

I think by making all the other characters silent as well it took away from the story and what's more important, it took away from the isolation of the father character. It could have been a great symbol, father loses son, loses voice as well, but they really wanted to stick to the concept of no dialogue with the rest of the characters as well, and it just doesn't make any sense.

The action scenes are mostly cool as you would expect from John Woo, but the editing feels like a mess a lot of times, creating odd scenes and logical jumps. For example Kinnaman pins two guys against a wall with his car, but in the next cut one of the guys is on the top of his car, how did he get there? There are a lot of these kinds of weird jumps in the movie, I really wonder if it's because they wanted to make the movie shorter or just didn't get the right shots to make the scenes make sense.

It's a pity because there are great shots in the movie, some scenes have great atmosphere and tension building, but it all falls apart in the next scene or shot, when some nonsensical thing happens.

My suggestion is to skip this one, especially if you like John Woo, you are going to be disappointed.

review_title: Woorst Movie Ever: A Disappointing Action Flick
review_detailed_main:
Woo at his worst. I recently had the misfortune of watching the much-hyped action movie, "Silent Night," and let me tell you, it was a colossal letdown. From start to finish, the film seemed more interested in showcasing mindless explosions than telling a coherent and engaging story.

The plot, if you can call it that, felt like a mere afterthought. It was a mishmash of clichés and tired tropes, with muted cardboard-cutout characters going through the motions of a generic action movie. The protagonist, a supposed "tough guy," lacked any depth or charisma, making it impossible to invest in his journey. I found myself struggling to care about the fate of the world, as the filmmakers failed to create any emotional connection with the audience.

But perhaps the most egregious offence was the excessive and gratuitous use of gunfire and explosions. It's as if the filmmakers believed that more equals a better movie. It doesn't and the constant barrage of it quickly became monotonous and numbing, overshadowing any potential excitement the action sequences could have generated.

Moreover, the special effects were subpar, resembling a video game from a decade ago rather than a blockbuster film in this day and age. The CGI felt lazy and uninspired, detracting from the overall viewing experience. I couldn't help but cringe at the poorly rendered explosions and lacklustre visual effects, wondering where the budget for this film actually went.

The dialogue was another sore point. The muted characters were cringe-worthy. It seemed as though the writers were absent due to the recent WGA writer strike so dialogue were non-existent.

Overall, "Silent Night" is a prime example of style over substance. If you're looking for a mindless spectacle with no regard for plot or character development, then this might be the film for you. However, if you prefer action movies with substance, compelling characters, and a thoughtfully crafted narrative, I suggest you steer clear of this cinematic disaster.

review_title: Silent Night" falls short of its potential, delivering a disappointing viewing experience despite intriguing initial premises.
review_detailed_main:
The concept of a mute protagonist seeking vengeance following a tragic event holds promise, but the execution of the narrative fails to capitalize on this idea.

One of the film's major drawbacks is its lack of coherent storytelling, exacerbated by rushed pacing and disjointed editing. The plot follows a father who witnesses his son's murder on Christmas Eve and embarks on a quest for justice despite being mute due to a previous injury. However, the decision to have the entire movie devoid of dialogue, even when the protagonist can still hear and potentially communicate through other means, results in confusion and undermines character development.

The absence of dialogue contributes to a lack of depth in the characters, making them feel dull and one-dimensional. Without meaningful interactions or development, the audience struggles to connect with the protagonist and other characters, further detracting from the overall viewing experience.

Additionally, the film's action sequences, typically a saving grace for movies of this genre, fall short of expectations. The fight scenes lack creativity and intensity, with basic choreography and uninspired execution. Furthermore, subpar CGI detracts from the realism of the action, further diminishing the film's impact.

Despite being directed by John Woo, known for his expertise in action filmmaking, "Silent Night" fails to deliver on its potential. Predictable villains and forgettable antagonists further contribute to the film's shortcomings, leaving little to redeem it.

In conclusion, "Silent Night" disappoints on multiple fronts, with a lack of cohesive storytelling, underdeveloped characters, and uninspired action sequences. While the premise held promise, the execution falls flat, resulting in a film that fails to leave a lasting impression. Viewers are advised to skip this one in favor of more engaging cinematic experiences.

review_title: Silent Night (2023): A Concept Lost in Silence, Frustratingly Unfulfilled
review_detailed_main:
Silent Night, with its ambitious premise of a dialogue-free narrative, initially presents an intriguing concept that holds promise. The idea of storytelling through silence and visual cues holds an allure, setting the stage for a potentially immersive and unique cinematic experience. However, the execution of this concept ultimately falls short, leaving the audience more frustrated than engaged.

The absence of dialogue, intended to heighten tension and convey emotions through visuals, unfortunately becomes a hindrance rather than an asset. While the silent approach has its moments of atmospheric intrigue, it struggles to sustain engagement throughout the film's duration. Instead of drawing viewers deeper into the narrative, the lack of verbal communication feels forced, leading to a disconnect and hindering character development.

The characters, despite commendable efforts from the cast, suffer from a lack of depth and meaningful interaction due to the absence of dialogue. As a result, the emotional impact and investment in their stories become diluted, making it challenging to establish a genuine connection with their experiences.

Moreover, the pacing and plot development suffer due to the reliance on visuals alone. What could have been a refreshing take on storytelling ends up feeling like a missed opportunity, with scenes that drag and fail to capitalize on the potential of a dialogue-free narrative.

While Silent Night should be commended for its bold attempt to explore a different form of cinematic storytelling, the execution ultimately falls flat. The concept, while intriguing on paper, struggles to sustain engagement and deliver a fulfilling viewing experience, leaving the audience longing for more substance and depth in its silent approach.

In the end, serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of succumbing to the hype generated by a well-edited trailer. While the film had moments of brilliance, they were fleeting and ultimately drowned out by a narrative that failed to deliver on its promises. Moviegoers expecting an unforgettable experience may find themselves sorely disappointed, realizing that the true masterpiece lay in the marketing rather than the film itself.

review_title: Decent action scenes, good revenge story, but something was missing

review_detailed_main:
Firstly, I stop reading reviews when they say they couldn't get through the whole film, because, I would say, how can you review a film when you haven't seen the whole story? I always watch to the end, though I also always choose a bit more carefully, and I picked this on a whim, based on the "John Wick" marketing and Joel Kinnaman. Then, I had to switch it off after about 30 minutes. So feel free to move onto the next review, or...

Having looked though some of the reviews here (after I switched it off), there are many valid reasons why this is such a mess. The opening sequence was silly but had that classic John Woo touch. What did it for me, was that the "emotional" build up was so overwrought and unbelievable, that I couldn't take it anymore. The acting was fine, but the film was so steeped in Technicolor, a la Wizard of Oz, that the world they existed was more like GTA. The "gangsters" were laughably stereotyped, which is ok in a video game when every character is an intentional stereotype to drive the gameplay, vs. This utter nonsense. It is a funny moment when the original Death Wish series manages to feel more emotional and connected with reality than this 2023 attempt, which played like a parody that was actually trying to be serious.

I am going to watch the rest, out of principal, and because I want to see at least a spark of John Woo's trademark gun opera, otherwise I will only be left with the 30 minutes or so of sugar laden emotional garbage I managed to sit through already. Though apparently, I have at least another 30 minutes of that to trudge through first.

What a waste of time! What a Z movie! Please do not give any chance to John Woo anymore. If you are an action movie fan who like good story, good directing and fun action... Go watch a B movie instead of this nonsense!

To get in action you need to watch 1 hour of bad acting, bad script and bad Rocky adaptation (for the exercise part). Violent, tick, story, well there is story, so tick. But ultimately this is a grim, grim film of a man in pure raw grief. Could never have a happy ending. In many ways it reminded me of 3 Billboards..... A great film, but half way through you realise that Frances mcCormand would get her revenge but never get her daughter back. We made it to the end, but it's 1 hour 44 minutes of my life that I can never get back. Nothing wrong with the activity, but a grim movie that I (and husband) disliked intensely. review_title: A fundamentally good example on how not to make a good action movie
review_detailed_main:
This is really a fundamentally good example on how not to make a good action movie. You have seen the lead actor Joel Kinnaman in a lot of better productions like in House of Cards and in the remake from 2014 called Robocop. In this movie I can't really see why he wasted his time even producing because it is really a mid action-movie at best. John Woo who is an expert at making action movies and has always been able to make decent movies despite hardcore action, like you see in the second Mission Impossible movie or in the first Red Cliff. But here it seems that he either ran out of ideas or that he just tried to be way too ambitious.

Because when he tries to make a more serious movie without too much dialogue than reminds you of a scuffed version of Death Wish where it is nowhere near the violence or intensity of those movies you end up with a bad result, and even the Bruce Willis version from 2018 is better than this movie. There are so many moments where it had been way more natural that the characters actually had some sort of dialogue especially between the lead character and his girlfriend. Inistead he just sits sobbing drinking alone, and the movie tries to create this dark and devious mood that you never can live yourself into. Also the movie is vashed away by flashbacks a highly emotional mood by the beginning, when actually John Woo could have given us the classic revenge thriller a lot faster without going through all the side roads, with the emotional arc and long planning sequence in the garage leading up to a kill spree on christmas. Yes I get that he misses his son but it does not have to go through half the movie to deal with that loss, and because of that the movie at times seem more like a drama movie than an actual action movie.

You have some good scenes with the high-octane opening sequence and it really looked better on the trailer than the on the final result. In addition you also got the fight scene right before the first hour is done, but rather than that the action scenes are done in a sloppy way where the main character is really not that challenged apart from the last fight. The action scenes really lack intensity and it is nothing like John Woo used to do in some of his earlier movies. You miss better characters and while these gangsters I am sure some of them could maybe be real characters you just feel they are portrayed to be too dumb and stupid to really be realistic.

Walking into I expected a more hardcore and less sentimental drama/action movie where the main character actually said a few lines: "John Wick" does not talk that much either but it works better with a little dialogue in these sort of movies, at least if you do something with a lot less dialogue you need better imagination and a better plot. Of course such movies like these never have a good plot, but then at least the action scenes need to be more intense the main character need more challenges and the characters need to be a lot better. Jason Bourne may at times have it easy because he is a one-man army too but at least he struggles a lot more in some of the fights and some of the action movies these days are just not able to actually make gunfights or fist fights that entertaining anymore. Of course you have seen a lot of revenge plots in action movies, but this is one of the most mid I have seen at least and for me it's a 5/10.

I dont recommend this to fans of revenge drama or artistic gunplay. Frankly it was very disappointing on all accounts. Woo has done better. MUCH better.

review_title: Well it's no Die Hard. Or Face Off, come to think of it...

But he certainly gives it a bloody good go, and after the tedious first half when our grieving father (who has his voicebox blown out early, hence the title) trains himself to be a superman to avenge his dead son, there is a number of impressive fight scenes during the intense climax involving cars, guns, martial arts, knives... the works.

What makes it even more tough is the aforementioned absence of proper dialogue from the movie, so it's very hard to relate to this couple who can't even properly communicate their feelings to each other.

Oh well. I can't help thinking the film would've been better if they'd ditched the stupid 'silence' gimmick and just done a straight action flick. Plus a bit more humour would've be nice... apart from the bizarre opening sequence involving hero wearing a Rudolf jumper whilst chasing the bad guys, there's not much funny here at all.

5/10 mostly for the last half-an-hour or so... once you get there, decide for yourself if it was worth it or not.

review_title: Gets Better After first 40% if the Movie
review_detailed_main:
So, I assume the low ratings are from people complaining about the slow, teary, pace of the first 40% of the movie. But, if you keep watching, it does get better after the 60% mark. As for that last 50% of the movie, see below.

"Silent Night" is a gripping and stylish action thriller that marks the triumphant return of legendary director John Woo to Hollywood. Starring Joel Kinnaman as a vengeful father who loses his voice and his son in a gang shootout on Christmas Eve, the film is a masterclass of visual storytelling, with minimal dialogue and maximum impact. Woo's signature style of slow-motion, dual-wielding, and doves is on full display, as Kinnaman's character embarks on a brutal and relentless quest for justice against the ruthless gang leader Playa, played by Harold Torres. The film also features a strong supporting cast, including Scott Mescudi as a sympathetic detective, Catalina Sandino Moreno as Kinnaman's estranged wife, and Angeles Woo as a badass policewoman. Silent Night is a must-see for fans of action cinema, as it delivers a thrilling and satisfying ride that will leave you breathless.

You have a common citizen with a self-imposed time limit of one year to avenge the death of his son, by killing the local gangsters.

Sadly, it's not as satisfying as I wanted it to be.. and feels like a movie that only and constantly shifts between 2 gears.

Pacing being the biggest issue. I understand the build-up and setup.. but there's always a better way to do it more efficiently. Constantly stopping the momentum becomes an annoyance. Then, the movie isn't trying to be fun, even once it gets going (with all the killing). There's a constant contrast of imagery and a will to maintain a more sentimental weight to the execution.. and that contrast hurts it, IMO, even if it's necessary due to the events and main character's thrust. It's somewhat realistic, which I appreciate, and not at all X-Mass-y.

But I can appreciate the "no dialogue" execution, "interesting" editing and camerawork, and decent action. At least it also ends in a somewhat satisfying manner.. if not predictable.

review_title: Lethargic for the first hour, Bombastic in the last!

review_title: Did some people forget about silent movies?

That's all I really have to say, I'm just going to fill up the rest of the text for required characters with periods now.....

We have all heard this term now and again! This movie proves it true, visuals in movies are always better than long drawn out dialogues between characters, often about non-trivial feelings, who is in the right, what gender and race is better or more oppressed and so on that we see in every movie and tv show for far too long now.

It's a standard revenge action movie with an average Joe, i don't think i will remember or re-watch but for a one time sitting it was a perfect escape from the garbage that we are force fed and what to think and believe to be a "good person"

The acting is ok. No Academy Awards for this movie. If you want violence and action, John Woo will bring it. Other than that, his attempt to get the audience emotionally involved doesn't really work.

If you want an action/revenge story without too much thinking, Silent Night will fit right in.

It's worth a look if nothing else is on.

review_title: No Dialogue? Challenge Accepted Says John Woo!
review_detailed_main:
I had intended to watch this movie in theaters, but there were too many other movies I chose to pay for in theaters and missed out. It may have been good I did. I finally saw this on a streaming service and I was blown away. First, I usually run my sound system at level 20. I thought my ears were messed up and turned it to 25 and still heard very little. I had no idea this movie has nearly no dialogue. While movies have been able to pull this off for effect and purpose, I don't see why no other character in the movie could say anything. Lots of texting and sign language. I guess John Woo was challenged to direct a movie with no actual dialogue.

Second, this movie, while cliche to the max, could have been way more entertaining. Everyone loves a revenge / payback movie. However, this was a complete mess. The storytelling was all over the place, and without anyone actually talking, you, the viewer are left trying to learn how to read body language and texts. Lastly, the ending of this movie was more of a comedy than anything. I really don't know if John Woo was trolling the studio for the ending or what. review_title: Let's make a film without any dialogue...

I think one of the gangsters mumbled "f*** you" toward the end of the picture, but I wouldn't really say that that was dialogue. I was half expecting Marcel Marceau to pick up a phone at some point and utter the word "non." I started thinking that perhaps halfway during filming one of the actors lost their voice and the production company decided to just eliminate the dialogue to make it work. In other words, this dialogue-free production was such a bad idea, I believe it would have had to be a desperate one.

Based on the synopsis I read, I didn't expect much more than a shoot 'em up action movie with a lot of gritty inner-city hip-hop music and blaring gunfire. I probably would not have gone for a movie like this, but I was bored and I like Joel Kinnaman, but I usually prefer to hear him speak.

The movie was dialogue free, which was fine, but maybe they should have explored more about the characters. It wasn't exactly Christmas John Wick like I was hoping for.

review_title: An idea for a movie, that didn't stack up well.

review_detailed_main: After viewing the movie's trailer, my expectations were high, anticipating an outstanding film. Unfortunately, the actual viewing was disappointing. The screenplay, which seemed promising in the trailer, turned out to be lackluster. The dialogue lacked originality and the characters were underdeveloped. The film's direction failed to elevate the weak script, and the pacing was uneven, causing disengagement. Additionally, the acting was constrained, the cinematography unremarkable, and the editing lacked coherence. Overall, despite the promising trailer, the film failed to deliver a compelling experience, making the time spent watching it feel unfulfilling.

Silent Night, the the latest action movie from John Woo to hit theaters, and unfortunately, it falls short of expectations. While the film boasts some well-choreographed action sequences, it's ultimately let down by a predictable plot, mediocre acting, and a protagonist whose decisions often defy logic.

The action scenes are competently handled and provide moments of excitement. However, these thrills are fleeting as the film quickly falls back into a narrative rut we've seen countless times before. The story offers nothing new, and the uninspired script fails to generate any real suspense or intrigue.

Adding to the film's woes are the uninspired performances from the cast. While no one is outright terrible, the acting is largely forgettable. Even the usually charismatic Joel Kinnaman seems to be phoning it in, delivering a performance devoid of any real depth or emotion. Furthermore, his character's actions are often baffling and illogical, leaving the audience scratching their heads rather than rooting for his success.

Ultimately, Silent Night is a passable way to kill a couple of hours if you're desperate for some mindless action. However, with its derivative plot, uninspired performances, and questionable character choices, it's unlikely to leave a lasting impression.

review_title: WOO SAYS TO WICK, HOLD MY BEER...!
review_detailed_main: Director John Woo (Hard Boiled/The Killer) is back, on the big screen, in this interesting effort from last year. After losing his son during a yuletide drive-by by some Hispanic drug thugs, a distraught & now silent father (after getting shot in the neck where he loses his power of speech), Joel Kinnaman is on a mission to take down the ones who took his in a year's time even though his wife, Oscar nominee Catalina Sandino Moreno, fears she'll lose him in his quest & a cop, Kid Cudi, is on his tail to thwart his efforts. Using Kinnaman's silence carries over to the script itself where any dialogue heard is tangentially in the background leaving everything in the film motion & action based which almost becomes an antidote to something like the John Wick series, where Woo, the action master, shows all comers how he got to the top of the heap.

Personally, I can't understand the negative reviews. Silent Night is like a colorful mix of John Woo's earlier works. Is that bad? Not for me. Woo always stood for melodrama paired with grandiose and bloody action where logic always falls by the wayside stayed. But this isn't about logic either. It's about family, loss and revenge. Simple and poignant. Heroic Bloodshed meets New school is how I would describe it. Okay a lot of things are exaggerated in the action scenes, but that didn't appeal to me least disturbed, because Woo has always crossed the threshold into logical action at some point in his films and at a certain point simply unleashes a death ballet of blood and tears. I like Silent Night both in the action and in the quiet scenes and I have to admit that I had a tear in my eye at the end.
